reviews.review_msg: Of how boring his lectures are, I first thought Dr. May was a dud. However, later down - Dr. May revealed himself to be an incredibly caring and loving prof. He moved deadlines for your convenience, bumped up grades if the TAs were harsh (usually are). He has immense passion for his job and he is the nicest prof at SFU. Just reach out to him man.

SFUs #1 under-appreciated professor. My success with Indigenous pedagogy is thanks to him. He is a great choice no matter what level of course you take with him. He gives great feedback, is very timely with his suggestions and an absolute pleasure to work with. A great resource for any student looking to work on Indigenous topics. Amazing Prof!
does not release grades at all in a timely manner

Goes out of his way for his students, has helped me and other students find sources for our final papers after reading our prospectus. He fosters a wonderful environment in his classroom and discussions are always lively. Overall fantastic guy and great prof, put in even a little effort and you'll do well in the class.
Dr. May is a great professor and does amazing lectures and seminars.
Boring man.
Good professor, good talks and easy on grade.
Okay-ish class but difficult essays

Dr. May is a knowledgeable and caring prof. Not only is he very understanding of student circumstances but he is also just a nice guy. I found the grading criteria and expectations fair for an upper division course and I felt like I learned a lot. One of the best profs I have had and I am not even majoring in history. Need more profs like him.

The professor reads off of 60-70 slides of power point every lecture word for word and even for a history major it gets very boring. The course readings are too much for a 101 class. My first assignment was a B for not sufficient footnotes, next assignment I use way more to back my arguments and he bumped me up by literally 1 grade which was 79.

The lecture slides and the weekly readings are very long and boring. The lecture slides use unnecessarily hard vocabularies, and I often get lost when reviewing the slides because of the way he structures his slides. It doesn't help when the finals are based on ALL the lecture slides and weekly readings.

the prof is a nice guy but.... lectures are over 50+ slides and 30+ pages of weekly readings that did not really connect to the lectures? Tutorials were only questions about the readings, and it was worth 25% participation mark. Oh and I cant forget about the papers... 3000 words was not it. For a first year course it should not be this difficult.

Pretty similar qualms as the other people who have rated this prof. He is a good guy but for a first-year history course, the content and essay requirements are a bit crazy. Tutorial structure is also usually not related to lecture which is frustrating.

Lectures are very long and dull, he does not add any value to the slides. The weekly tutorials (participation marks) are based on lengthy boring readings that do not relate to the course content taught in lecture. There is an essay in the class that is 3000 words and is was too much for a first year class.  TA says he makes things WAY to hard.
I took 326 in the spring with Dr. May, and it is one of my favourite history classes. I suggest taking his history classes, since he is a great professor and one of the best in the department.
Best professor ever! He is very considerate. He a G of prof!!!
Dr. May is one of the best professors in the history department. I strongly recommend taking a class with him and he is also very friendly.

This was my second time taking a class with May, and I enjoyed it! Content is dry after a while, but that depends on one's historical interests. If you ask for more feedback, he will give you great feedback--so don't be afraid to communicate with him! Lots of reading, but it is expected for an upper-division history course.

This class was way too information heavy. Slides are jammed packed with information, with 60 slides per lecture. Readings for the tutorials averaged from 15-30 pages and are incredibly dry. The tutorials had mandatory participation, but the questions we'd be answering were only given during tutorial- why not give them with the readings!?

Prof May is very kind and cares a lot about his students. Participation is very important to your grade and he requires you to not just attend but to participate in the discussion as well. My only issue with him is that he is a slow grader, and going into the take-home final we have only received one grade back.

Nicholas May is a very nice professor, I have no qualms with him simply as a dude, but his class sucked. The lectures were useless as he just reads his slides and my tutorial for this course didnt help either, seeing as how the tutorial readings have nothing to do with the actual lessons. Also, the tests and papers are way too hard for intro level.

He is kind, understanding, and very helpful to his students. However, his lectures have a lot of information, which gets dry and boring to pay attention to for 2 hours straight. For a first year course, its overwhelming, especially the readings he provided. Exam consisted of 2 essays (big idea topics) & defining terms. Straightforward simple exam.

Very high % of grade is on participation, not just attendance. 3 Readings per week, ~90 pages average. Slow but easy grader. Very approachable, nice, and inclusive (so don't worry about participating). Even when you give really bad answers, he doesn't react negatively or denies your opinion. Only gripe is that he's a slow grader.

Frankly, May is not a bad prof prof. My issue comes from the fact that despite there being 4 total graded assignments over the semester, we only ever received a grade on 1 single assignment so we had no clue how we were doing by the time the final came around. Also to note this was by far the hardest Hist course I have taken so far as a Hist major

Dr May is a really sweet guy, nerdy and very well spoken. His lecture slides were layed out nicely and I really loved the perspectives which he brought into lecture. Dr May has a very quiet voice and his lectures sometimes put me to sleep. Really interesting course content.  If you enjoy history, you will enjoy this course.

Seminar was great as everyone participated and the prof did well to facilitate conversation. In lower and upper div classes, if you do the work and readings you will do well in all his classes. He is also a fair marker who provides suitable feedback where necessary. Lower div lectures are very dry but just do the work and you will succeed.

Lectures were very long and dull with 70 slide power points, with paragraphs directly copied. Had weekly mandatory reading which were 20-40 pages long that we had to discuss in tutorial. Tutorial was no help for understanding the lecture. extremely boring take on the history of canada

Professor May was amazing and very passionate about this course. He cares about his students and is willing to always answer your questions. If you pay attention and review the slides and readings it is possible to get a very high mark. The readings were very interesting and tutorials were fun. Always participate as it is worth 25 percent of grade.

Professor May is very welcoming and approachable. His lectures can be a little dull, but it's obvious how passionate he is about history. If you put in the effort to keep up with lectures and the readings, then you should be able to do well. He's also very good at answering questions-- go to his office hours!

Lectures are boring and content heavy. Vague instructions on essays and minimal feedback on how to improve. Mandatory tutorial participation to discuss extremely boring readings (~40 pages in length). Final is on all lectures (~60 slides each and slides are full of text) and all readings. Unreasonably difficult for a 100 level course.

Expected us to read 11 scholarly papers each around 20-35 pages long and study his 11 45-70 slide long power points for the final exam. The only practice received is mandatory participation in tutorial to mind-numbingly discuss the scholarly papers weekly. Only take this if needed or you are really passionate about history, very self-directed

Copied whole pages from textbooks and put them directly onto the slides he uses during lectures. Well, the slides are very informative and give a good understanding of the topic there were about 60-80 slides a lecture all with small font and lots of writing. The final lecture requires us to study 13 of these PowerPoints + 13 weekly readings.

Nicholas May is very considerate and continues to show how much passion he has for history. His lectures are pretty heavy with information; however, he still is able to keep the class engaged with interesting points. There is a research essay that is tough but beside that definitely a class I would take again.
Dr. May is a great prof!! Lots of reading but you learn a lot! You need to read every class but not a lot of homework. I would take his class again!
Nice guy. Isn't clear what he wants on assignments. Lectures unfocused.

I credit Professor May for being one of the most approachable and helpful teachers at SFU. There are a lot of readings to do to be prepared for his classes, but if you do, you will do well. I took this class for my indigenous requirement as a teacher, so I recommend it to anybody planning to do PDP. He grades his assignments tough, but fair.
Great Professor. His seminars were very informative and engaging. Very helpful about essays and sources and stuff like that. Definitely would recommend!

Dr. May is an excellent professor. You can tell he really cares about his field of study. Participation definitely matters and if you find yourself struggling with anything at all in class, don't be scared to reach out to him during office hours or a quick e-mail (100% will help)! Also doesn't hurt that he's cute :-)

He is clear in his lecture and he usually does an hour lecture and an hour of tutorial which is not bad. However, for the essays, he expects perfect almost a master' level. He does not give clear feedback on why you got a lower grade making it harder to get a better grade for the next essay. He is slow at grading papers and responding to emails.
